conclusion: To find the magnitude of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the coil, we can use Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction.

The induced EMF \( \mathcal{E} \) in a rotating coil in a uniform magnetic field is given by: \[ \mathcal{E} = n B A \omega \sin(\omega t) \] where: - \( n \) is the number of turns of the coil, - \( B \) is the magnetic field strength, - \( A \) is the area of the coil, - \( \omega \) is the angular velocity, and - \( \sin(\omega t) \) accounts for the rotation.
Calculate the area \( A \) of the coil: \[ A = l_{AB} \times l_{BC} = 0.2 \, \text{m} \times 0.5 \, \text{m} = 0.1 \, \text{m}^2 \]
Since timing starts when the coil plane passes through the neutral plane, \( t = 0 \) and \( \sin(\omega t) = \sin(0) = 1 \).

premise: Substitute the known values into the equation \( \mathcal{E} = n B A \omega \)

conclusion: Thus, the magnitude of the induced electromotive force in the coil is \( 314 \sin(100\pi t) \, \text{V} \).
